displayed_text: Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. Healthcare Professional: He had a Buick Encore; that’s a nice car, too. Family Member: Yeah, that was a beautiful car. Doctor: Yeah, so now he’s. So she was sort of joking that if you get any girls’ phone calls, that’s the reason he’s getting them, not - Family Member: Oh my god! Patient: Yeah, “Mom, can I borrow your car?”

Patient: No. Doctor: You get them? Patient: Typically not. Actually, I never have. Doctor: You want one? Patient: Um, going into this, hearing from other patients, they say it’s advisable. I’ve heard, I don’t know. I, uh Doctor: I’m a big fan. Patient: Then, I guess I will. Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the

Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Family Member: At home. Patient: Oh they’re stretching; they’re not - Doctor: Yeah, good, they’re not heavy-duty. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: No .No. No.

Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean this is. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I have to say, though, that you look better today post radiation than before we started. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were really uncomfortable. You know? Patient: Yeah. And now I did have some.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: I just had a meeting with him last week. Patient: Oh tell him I said hello next time you see him. Doctor: Yep. I was uh, I was talking to him. I said you got any idea? He goes, yeah, no, just do the chemo too. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyways. So I picked his brain. Patient: I mean, not, and please no, no offense. Doctor: No. No. Patient: Oh, yeah. I mean he I consider him part of my team. Doctor: Absolutely. Me too. Patient: You know? Doctor: Me too. Me So.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay. Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.

Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: You give the flu shot. You hope to try to prevent it from getting worse. Family Member: Worse. Um hum. Doctor: So the vaccine therapy wakes up your body’s immune system to try to fight the cancer by itself. Family Member: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: We also have information that at least in the, you know, African American men- Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t think there’s a conspiracy. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: If that’s where you’re going. Family Member: Right. Yeah. Doctor: This is not a trial. It’s an FDA-approved study. Where there is a trial- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar. Family Member: Right. Doctor: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Mass. Doctor: Which we know because you had a biopsy in the past which proved that to be so. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Doctor: And uh the bone is not that clear whether there’s anything in there. To me it doesn’t look like there’s any cancer in there. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: It looks like you have arthritis all the usual goodies that we’ve talked about, but mostly everything is here. Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic.

Patient: B___. Family Member: B___. Doctor: And you got it the same day you saw me or you got, you went over there earlier today or-? Family Member: He got it done here today. They made an appointment here today. Doctor: Okay. Huh, but normally you go to B___? Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I had the blood test done this morning. Is that what we were reading off for the PSA this morning? Doctor: Yep. Yeah. You might give me a little bit longer than two weeks since you don’t go to Medicare, huh, until, huh, Friday. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. March first it kicks in. I’ve got the card on me if you need it. Family Member: I’ve also got that, our insurance too. Doctor: Okay. So I just emailed the pharmacist to let them know what we’re thinking, huh, to get you started, that’s you’ve switched to Medicare, and that they might end up looking next week. Huh, so hopefully, in the next week or two we’ll know where you are.

Family Member: It’s got the stuff that good for your eyes in it. Doctor: Vitamin E? Family Member: Yeah. Something like that. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know what it’s got in it. Family Member: Alright. Next time. Doctor: Next time so we can look at it. Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC.

Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it. Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it.

Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah so if you call and say hey who’s out there with uh you know at the R___ Branch, um… Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s - there’s many, there’s many, but they literally are all good. Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ … Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: …and operates out of the uh works out of the uh W____ location. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Makes it easier for us. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know your numbers always suggest that you’re dry. You know like you’re just a tad dehydrated. It always runs a little high. The other number we check is the B.U.N. or the bun.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they-
